summary.text_en: Hero of Alexandria described a device called the 'Aeolipile' (Ball of Aeolus) in his work 'Pneumatica'. It was a hollow metal sphere that spun when driven by steam. It is the first known 'heat engine' (converting thermal energy into mechanical energy) and 'reaction turbine' in human history. Although it was treated merely as a 'temple toy' or 'philosophical curiosity' at the time and not put to practical use, it proves that the principle of steam power was discovered 1700 years before the Industrial Revolution.
key_points_en: Based on the 'Reaction Principle' / Newton's Third Law
Considered a 'toy' rather than a practical machine
Proved antiquity possessed the knowledge of steam power
Ancestor of the modern 'jet engine' and 'steam turbine'

story.text_en: Hero was a famous engineer who loved designing automata. The construction of the Aeolipile was simple: a sealed cauldron of water (the boiler) connected by tubes to a hollow sphere above. When the water boiled, steam rose into the sphere and escaped through two bent nozzles on the equator (pointing in opposite directions). Based on the reaction principle (like a deflating balloon), the escaping steam spun the sphere rapidly. Although it spun fast (up to 1500 rpm), it had very little 'torque' and couldn't drive heavy machinery. Combined with the abundance of cheap slave labor, there was no economic incentive to develop this 'labor-saving machine'.

fun_facts.text_en: The name 'Aeolipile' comes from 'Aeolus' (the Greek god of the wind) and 'pila' (Latin for ball), meaning 'Ball of Aeolus'.
Hero also invented the world's first 'automatic doors' and 'vending machine' (coin-operated holy water dispenser), using steam and pneumatic principles to create 'miracles' in temples.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine a balloon full of air. If you let it go, the air shoots out the back, and the balloon flies forward. This is how a 'rocket' works.
Hero's machine used 'steam' instead of 'air' and 'spinning' instead of 'flying'.
He boiled water to make steam, which shot out of nozzles on a metal ball, pushing the ball to spin round and round. This was the first time humans used 'heat' (fire) to create 'motion' (rotation).

applications.text_en: It is a form of 'radial steam turbine'. Modern power plants also use steam turbines, just vastly more complex and efficient ones.

impact.text_en: Hero's Aeolipile represents the 'missed Industrial Revolution'. It proves that the Ancient Greeks understood the basic physics of steam power, but due to a lack of precision engineering (for high pressure) and economic need (slavery), the technology lay dormant for 1700 years. It wasn't until Papin (`papin_piston_1690`) and Newcomen (`newcomen_engine_1712`) that the power of steam was re-awakened for work.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Ctesibius (early Alexandrian inventor, considered the father of pneumatics, who heavily influenced Hero)
Archimedes (his engineering and screw pump principles provided the basis for Hero's mechanical designs)

influenced.contribution_en: Taqi al-Din (Ottoman engineer who described a steam jet device to turn a spit in 1551, similar to the Aeolipile)
Giovanni Branca (designed a machine using a steam jet to spin a turbine wheel, a direct continuation of Hero's design)
Denis Papin (although he switched to a piston design, he was inspired by Hero's writings on steam and vacuum)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Hero not only invented the steam engine, he proved science could be 'fun'. He was the engineer who built miracles for the temples.

quiz.question_en: Why did Hero's 'Aeolipile' (steam engine), invented in the 1st century AD, NOT spark the Industrial Revolution?
options_en: Because it didn't spin at all
Because it was seen as a 'toy' or 'philosophical curiosity' with no demand for practical application
Because the Roman Emperor banned it
quiz.explanation_en: Although it worked, it was inefficient (low torque). More importantly, in a slave-based society, labor was cheap, so there was no economic demand for 'labor-saving' machines. It was used mainly for creating 'magical' effects in temples.
